Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Discovery by Computation, Theory and Experiment
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professors Jeffrey Evanseck, Jeffry Madura, and colleagues of Duquesne University host an REU site supported by the REU Sites Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry. This site impacts the professional chemistry careers and education of undergraduates and faculty from institutions with limited research infrastructure as well as those from underrepresented populations. This is achieved through establishment of meaningful, year-round, and long-term research collaborations driven by the need for academic productivity and excellence in undergraduate training. The model builds research teams of student-faculty pairs recruited from Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs), Historically Black Colleges (HBCs) and the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) institutions. These collaborators are integrated with extramurally funded research groups from Duquesne. The model is proven to perpetuate itself, where invested collaborations ultimately mature to independent funding. The broader impacts of this work include meaningful research experiences to attract and retain the nation's diverse student talent pool. This will have the consequence of enhancing and diversifying the U.S. workforce by adding experts in the fields of chemistry and biochemistry.

This project focuses on strong financial and infrastructure support of research collaborations that invigorate faculty from PUIs, HBCs, and LSAMP institutions. These faculty in turn directly impact students and learning environments at their home institutions. REU students have novel chemical research experiences in exciting and broad scientific themes, such as nanotechnology, homeland security, pharmaceutical drug design, forensic sciences, and chemical biology. Each student works directly with two faculty mentors in the laboratory (from the home institution and Duquesne). Students also consult with a theoretical faculty liaison, since each REU project is supplemented by well-defined computational components to expand the students' experience. REU students receive explicit training to reinforce the scientific method, scientific writing and speaking, ethics, safety, and workshops on state-of-the-art instrumentation to complement their experimental research and build invaluable skill sets. Each student has the opportunity to present their research locally, regionally, and nationally to expand their professional exposure and networking to make more informed career decisions and best prepare for graduate school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have been successful in accomplishing our goals in the "REU Site: Discovery by Computation, Theory and Experiment" grant (CHE-1659823) at Duquesne University. Specifically, we have created (1) research opportunities with regional impact in exciting and broad scientific themes, such as nanotechnology, organic synthesis, advanced instrumentation, forensic sciences, pharmaceutical drug design and chemical biology to make significant advances in chemical research and discovery. Moreover, we have provided research opportunities for underrepresented students, female scientists, and those who might not otherwise have the opportunity of a research experience, particularly those from institutions where research programs are limited in the Pittsburgh region. Next, we have (2) enhanced scholarly production for those in the Pittsburgh region. We promoted and emphasized the need for presentation and publication for both faculty and students. Publication builds student resumes, advances faculty careers, increases the chance of students joining the U.S. scientific workforce, and is one avenue that justifies the NSF/REU program. Third, we (3) provided training on advanced instrumentation. Hands-on experience and training of students is delivered by academic and industrial experts on the fundamentals of molecular modeling, the use of state-of-the-art computational facilities, and modern software to advance experimental research. Specialized workshops were offered in conjunction including: literature searching, theory and computation, nuclear magnetic spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, surface chemistry, synthetic analysis, and light spectroscopy. Next, we (4) enriched student communication skills. A unique effort that trains students how to speak and write "like a chemist" has been integrated into the entire ten-week summer research experience based upon an implementation of the scientific method. Students were separated into cohorts, giving oral and written presentations every other week coinciding with the principal steps of the scientific method. Fifth, we (5) deepened student's awareness of ethical behavior. An ethics component was offered to the students to address an ethical issue. The experience concluded with the presentation of a critical assessment of the ethical issue chosen by the group, along with an invited expert keynote speaker at the annual regional ethics symposium. All students had the opportunity of presenting their research on an ethical topic at the final Pittsburgh Regional Ethics Symposium at Duquesne University with more than 100 student abstracts, 16 team oral presentations and a keynote speaker. Finally, we (6) offered career development and networking opportunities. Professional development was provided through exposure to world-renowned industrial experts from Gaussian (Doug Fox), academic faculty, weekly seminars, and travel to national ACS meetings. Our efforts and accomplishments feed directly into the intent of the REU program by using meaningful research experiences to attract and retain the nation's diverse student talent pool. This has the added consequence of enhancing and diversifying the U.S. workforce by adding experts in the fields of chemistry or biochemistry.
